results.title: [Watching television]
results.brief_description: Short comic film made in 1958 by Graham Foster and friends to send to his relatives in New Zealand. Structured as ‘a mini sitcom’ the film features a group of friends engrossed in the act of watching television and has a voiceover by Foster. Features television advertising from the late 1950s. Companion piece to ‘A Kiwi in Exile’.

results.title: Interviews with the builders of ACMI @ Federation Square
results.brief_description: There are two segments - the first with Philip Walsh walking down and back along the old platform 15, 16 during demolition and the second part (and the priority) is of Don Bates presenting the drawings to Nigel Milan from SBS

results.title: In continuo
results.brief_description: The film begins with a woman scrubbing a wall. Very soon, as burly men put on their white aprons, we realise that we are inside the world of the abattoir. Wordlessly the men begin to sharpen their knifes and their hatchets. The soundtrack is the music of the abattoir floor. We see none of the slaughter but we see the after-effects of the butchery and we hear the sounds of death. Finally, we see the blood and waste seep into the earth and we are left to contemplate the brutality of something called civilisation.

results.title: Sweet things
results.brief_description: Marley Flory says “In the little town of Broadford Bay everything is perfect and things NEVER go wrong. But even the sweetest of things can be deadly. An animated trailer for a new teen series”

results.title: Found
results.brief_description: This film effectively communicates a story as well as the emotions behind it with little reliance on dialogue. Annabelle explains the film ‘ A girl longs for connection with her absent father. A chance encounter brings new hope’ This film won the ACMI award for original sound in diegesis 2002.
